timeline.message: Add Gradle task support for arg file generation

timeline.bodyText: Is this basically just a copy of the existing test, but using PSVM instead? Would it be possible to keep this in the existing test class, or would that be too messy you think?
timeline.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: Due to the messiness of the sysprop backup/restore, I chose to extract it to a separate class. I'm still worried about parallelism or unwanted side-effects of this, so we should kill this.
replies.author: DPUkyle

timeline.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: Yes, I'll try with default access.
replies.author: DPUkyle

timeline.bodyText: Although this logic is quite simple, it would probably be worthwhile to refactor this into its own utility class within :gradle-plugins, something like ArgumentFileBuilder (I say "___Builder" to stress that static utilities are unmaintainable) which handles creating the temp file and returning its "ID" (e.g. @/something/something). I think this would be a simple refactoring and would allow us to easily reuse it later, plus it removes complexity from this class.
timeline.author: evanw555

replies.bodyText: Added class ArgumentFileGenerator. Note that it can't live in restli-tools as pegasus-plugins has no dependency on it.
replies.author: DPUkyle

timeline.bodyText: Can you add a TODO here which says that we want to refactor this tool into a nicer CLI app using Commons-CLI?
timeline.author: evanw555

timeline.bodyText: Similar comment as the one above, there should be a utility class within :restli-tools which handles the parsing side of things. Although this logic here isn't too complicated, this will proactively keep this sort of stuff from exploding if we need to extend or reuse it, plus it keeps this class clean.
timeline.author: evanw555

timeline.bodyText:
Since this utility is only accessible within the :gradle-plugins module, I think it's safe to let this method assume the temp dir to be Task#getTemporaryDir. This would make the code simpler from the caller's POV. What do you think?
Edit: Is it done this way because Gradle temp dirs are associated with a particular task?

replies.bodyText: Yes I did it this way to use as few Gradle APIs as possible; if we use Task#getTempoaryDir() as default storage for the arg File, the caller would have to pass a reference to the Task object, which is kind of icky too. Let's leave it as-is.
replies.author: DPUkyle

replies.bodyText: Now I get it, makes sense.
replies.author: evanw555

timeline.bodyText: Calling this param files is confusing, since it doesn't refer to the arg file itself but rather to its inputs. I'd suggest renaming to args, entries, values, inputs, or something along those lines. In addition, we may reuse this utility later in a case where the args aren't necessarily filepaths.

replies.bodyText: Fair enough - although I don't intend this to become the "restli standard". We need to stop passing arguments via sysprops on the CLI, and use a proper framework like jcommander. I'm OK with commons-cli too if it can support the argfile syntax. Otherwise I strongly recommend jcommander.
replies.author: DPUkyle

replies.bodyText: Ah, I see. So for now, this will hold us over, and we'll potentially have to use it if we run into the same issue for another task in the near future. The long-term vision will be to migrate all our tools to C-CLI or JCommander.
replies.author: evanw555
